body: $ZIM  ZIM is very likely sandbagging here with regard to the value-add of it's new tech... They're playing this card close to their chest in order to delivery some unanticipated positive surprises going forward...
$ZIM  Actually
created_at: ZIM shareholders would very likely benefit if they diverted some of their excess cash flow into buybacks rather than divs and/or debt reduction... Their debt is materially insignificant
column3: and their divs are very generous... Engaging the buyback machine to enhance shareholder value is not without merit
column4: and could have an out-sized positive impact on the shares...

body: $ZIM If I read one more person suggestion "Buyback Shares"  I'm going to say really bad things about them! LOL
$ZIM  ZIM here is a private equity dream stock... After cash
created_at: the business is essentially priced at zero
column3: which is why it's very likely that private equity is positioning here... PE generally avoids the shipping sector like the plague... But they're sooooo starved for yield and deep value
column4: they're actively positioning to take over shipping sector operators like ZIM... ZIM has no net debt
column5: excellent long-term cash flow generation potential
column7: and it's metrics are showing deeply undervalued forward valuations... Their model is flexible and their structure is streamlined and efficient... But the most interesting thing about ZIM is that the market seems to be ignoring the positive impact of its new technological developments with regard to its platform
column8: which will increase its competitiveness and profitability going forward... Leadership probably needs to provide more color to the quantitative value of their new tech advancements...

body: $ZIM  The reality in the container shipping world is that spot rates continue to follow a well-forecasted
column3: while contract rates  move sideways to higher based on the reality that container ship availability will actually contract moving into 2023 (despite the hype of looking only at new builds
column4: and ignoring extensively delayed scrapping due to excess demand)... The convergence of these factors along with inflation will cause rates to stabilize and form a new base run rate much higher than pre-pandemic levels...
